folder: 109-111 Division Street - Pike Street, Manhattan, NY
title: 109-111 Division Street - Pike Street

folder: Division Street & Pike Street., Manhattan, NY
text:
113 Division Street, south side, east of Pike Street, showing the Scharlin snuff shop and its wooden identification. Sandy the "Scotch Indian" has had a series of adventures since this photo was taken. Confiscated by the Manhattan Department of Borough of Works for obstructing the sidewalk, he was hauled off to the city dump in April, heartless officials paying no heed to his antiquity or authentic folk-art beauty. Rescued when his owner paid a $1.00 fine, the snuff shop figure was sold to a collector. This photo was reproduced on page 68 of the published volume "Changing
New York. "
January 26, 1938
Berenice Abbott, photo
Federal Art Project
Neg ~77
Another copy filed under "Occupations - Tobacco"

folder: Division Street & Allen Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Division Street, east from Allen Street, showing nearly completed Second Avenue Elevated Railroad.

This was the last of the elevated lines to be built, service being inaugurated in 1880.  Elevated construction had begun in 1867 with a single trunk line, operated by cables and stationary engine, on Greenwich street from Battery Place to Cortlandt Street, and subsequently extended up to Ninth Avenue and 30th Street. By 1876 the financial structure of the elevated companies was in shape, and construction of the Sixth and Third Avenue lines begun.  By 1880 substantially the present lines on Manhattan were completed; but steam was used till 1903.

1879. (handwritten--c. 1914-5)

Ewing Galloway, Photographer.
